title: Hyndburn Paid £420K to B3P Services While Company Had No Active Directors
author: AI DOGE Investigation
excerpt: Hyndburn Borough Council paid over £420,000 to B3P Services Ltd during a period when the company had no active directors registered at Companies House — a critical governance failure.

blocks.title: £420K Paid to Company With No Directors
blocks.subtitle: Hyndburn's largest single supplier breach reveals critical due diligence gap

items: B3P Services Ltd received £420,200 while having no active directors
Highest-value breach across all three East Lancashire councils
Payments continued despite Companies House flagging director absence
No evidence of enhanced due diligence before contract award

blocks.heading: The Scale of the Breach
blocks.content: B3P Services Ltd stands out as the most serious supplier compliance failure identified in our analysis of East Lancashire council spending. While Hyndburn paid £1.1 million total to suppliers during active Companies Act breaches, B3P Services alone accounts for 38% of that amount.

blocks.heading: What 'No Active Directors' Means
blocks.content: A company with no active directors cannot legally make decisions, enter contracts, or authorise payments. It typically indicates either: (1) All directors have resigned without replacement, (2) The company is being wound down, or (3) There has been a serious administrative failure. None of these scenarios justify continued council payments.

blocks.heading: Pattern of Governance Failure
blocks.content: This case represents the extreme end of a broader problem. Hyndburn paid 17 different suppliers during active breaches, totaling £1.1 million. However, B3P Services is unique in both the scale of payments and the severity of the compliance failure — no directors means no corporate governance whatsoever.

blocks.heading: Due Diligence Questions
blocks.content: Our analysis raises several questions about Hyndburn's supplier verification processes: Was Companies House checked before contract award? Were ongoing monitoring checks performed? Why did payments continue after the director situation was flagged? What services were provided during this period, and who authorised them?
